issue.title: ConsoleInteractionTest.py: `test_ask_for_actions_and_apply` defined twice
issue.body:
Change the name of one of the function to something more appropriate.
difficulty/newcomer

issue.title: Setting.py: Include the memory location in all __repr__
issue.body: The default __repr__ on CPython emits the memory location of the object.  This should also be done for the coala overrides of __repr__ in Settings.

issue.title: ConsoleInteraction.py: `color_letter` function is buggy
issue.body:
color_letter function in ConsoleInteraction module does not work as expected when there is an upper case letter after the upper case letter in parenthesis.
e.g. If input line is Edit (C)ommit Message then output is Edit (M)ommit Message

issue.title: Coala's AGPL coverage
issue.body:
Hi Coala maintainers,
Can you help clarify AGPL coverage in Coala's case? Specifically, are the modifications made by Coala, which would get put into the input source code, covered by AGPL?
Your clarification will help evaluate the technology selection. I'd be helpful If you could clarify your interpretation in the Q&A page.
Thanks,
Brian

issue.title: coala -A throws exception on EOF signal
issue.body:
Overview Description
Sending EOF signal to coala -A results in EOFError
Steps to Reproduce

run coala with -A or --single-action flag
press Ctrl-D(EOF signal)
EOFError is dumped to the console

Actual Results
EOFError is dumped on console with the following traceback
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/amol/anaconda3/envs/coala/bin/coala", line 11, in <module>
    load_entry_point('coala', 'console_scripts', 'coala')()
  File "/home/amol/GitHub/coala/coalib/coala.py", line 121, in main
    return mode_normal(console_printer, None, args, debug=debug)
  File "/home/amol/GitHub/coala/coalib/coala_modes.py", line 29, in mode_normal
    debug=debug)
  File "/home/amol/GitHub/coala/coalib/coala_main.py", line 116, in run_coala
    choice = input(line)
EOFError

Expected Results
A better message like, Found EOF. Exiting gracefully. should be shown and the process must exit with status code 0
Reproducibility
100%
Additional Information:
difficulty/low
coala/main

issue.title: Missing comma in docstring
issue.body:
In the file Git_Basics.rst, the following line:

As people work on coala new commits will be added.

can be changed to

As people work on coala, new commits will be added.

to sound better.
This can be a newcomer issue.

issue.body:
If you read the documentation on Writing a Native Bear, you'll find that there are some articles missing.
Please add the same.
A good newcomer issue.

issue.title: TestUtilities.execute_coala should check for timeouts
issue.body:
If there was a timeout during a test using execute_coala, pytest-timeout will emit Failed: Timeout >35.0s (number may change) and the timeout failure will be lost inside execute_coala/bear_test_module.
The test module will continue with the assertions, and cause various errors, as these coala output will be in a strange incomplete state.
This is one of the problems affecting #5571 and #5390
A quick workaround is to detect Failed: Timeout is stderr inside execute_coala and re-raise the problem with the complete stderr and stdout for debugging purposes.

issue.title: Provide support for non utf-8 encodings
issue.body:
coala currently only supports utf-8 encodings. Before merging this
we need to add support for non utf-8 encodings to coala-utils.
Some bears like SpellCheckBear have external linters which only
support utf-8 encodings. To solve this the bears should describe
the encoding it can handle followed by coala creating a temporary
file in the linter's accepted encoding (Converting utf-16 to utf-8)
Some encodings have glyphs which are not in unicode and can't be
transcoded to utf16/32. We should write test to catch such
exceptions.
Closes #3862

comments.bodyText:
Currently, 5 style guides are supported across 4 languages (cpp, java, html, python).
coala --init language style --files = [files to lint] will run style guide lint on the required files
Eg:-
coala --init python pep8 --files = a.py will check a.py against pep8 guidelines.
@jayvdb @RaiVaibhav @Nosferatul @ksdme @margobra8 Can you review this PR ?
Check the Travis CI build faling. Exit code 1 is given when running pip install coala-bears.zip[alldeps] --pre -U. Other than that, commits LGTM.

Passing now, could merge
cc: @Nosferatul or @li-boxuan
There is still a problem with Travis. I have temporarily fixed it by adding ruamel.yaml<=0.15.0.

The second commit uses https://github.com/PrajwalM2212/coala-styles for configuration files.
The first commit has configuration files within the repo.
Based on the needs we can choose one of them.

@ksdme Can you see if this approach is okay.
I have made this into an independent command.
User can follow lang:style:files format. Also for the default or all or cli  section files can be specified as well.
So we can use something like coala -g python:pep8:a.py cpp:google:b.cpp --files c
This will generate a coafile that's fully functional out of the box.
This will generate
[python]
bears = PEP8Bear, PycodestyleBear
language = Python
files = a.py

[cpp]
bears = CPPLintBear
language = CPP
files = b.cpp

[cli]
config = .coafile
files = c
generate_config = python:pep8:a.py,cpp:google:b.cpp

I should still write tests. I thought you could see the approach while I write tests.
Tests have been added.
@ksdme The documentation PR for this coala/documentation#599
@ksdme Can you review this?

I love the approach except for CLI section. I know we handle CLI section in an unnecessarily special way, but you shouldn't include that in the generated config. The way it should work ideally is to have a generate an all section and have every other section be a child of all. Such as all.python, all.c etc and dump all the options such as files in it. Is there any error handling built in, for example what happens if I only pass python:pep8 and omit the third field? also can I pass multiple file patterns for each style say python:google:*.py,**/**/one/*.py
But if this system works for now, I am good with it. We can make improvements later.

One other feature addition we can have is to support exclusions in -g syntax i.e. lang:author:files:excludes. Also, it would be good to assume that files=** and excludes= if they are missing. This would make it more flexible.

also can I pass multiple file patterns for each style say python:google:*.py,**/**/one/*.py

Yes

Is there any error handling built in, for example what happens if I only pass python:pep8 and omit the third field?

Yes
If files and excludes are missed default values will be taken.

One other feature addition we can have is to support exclusions in -g syntax i.e. lang:author:files:excludes. Also, it would be good to assume that files=** and excludes= if they are missing. This would make it more flexible.

Added

I know we handle CLI section in an unnecessarily special way, but you shouldn't include that in the generated config.

cli has been replaced with all

Appveyor is failing due to timeout on coalaTest.py. I have not made changes in this part of the codebase.
Not sure if appveyor build is broken or if there is a problem on appveyor side.  I will try to build again tomorrow.
appveyor build is passing as well.
Nice! Looking good

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.title: Result.py: Add actions attribute
issue.body:
This adds a new attribute actions to the Result class. It is a list of action objects which are specific to the origin to that Result.
This also makes changes in ConsoleInteraction module and Processing module to incorporate these additions and support bears to define their own actions.

issue.body:
Run initialize_options first and instead of call use run command.
Fixes #5970

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.title: Do not error hard because a dependency of a bear has been updated
issue.body:
Currently, upon a simple load of bears, we implicitly check every single dependency to see if it's exactly as any given bear hard pins to antequated versions and fail hard if you are even slightly off. I don't see a reason this should be the case as this is Python; it's not coala's concern whether I've installed a later isort version than it expects, especially not at runtime.
This simple fix merely resolves each entrypoint instead, which is really what we're trying to do anyway.

comments.bodyText:

btw load() function doesn't have argument 'require'.

Nice solution, but the last line of the commit message needs to refer to an issue, not the same PR.
I suggest using "Related to #4085" or "Related to #3545" as the two closest open issues to the problem that you are solving.
Or you can create a new issue about it.
Then, the other problem with this lovely hack is we need to know what is the minimum version of setuptools/pkg_resources where this hack works.
What would be really nice (but not mandatory) is if this little hack was packaged up in a separate repo & pypi package with its own CI to ensure it keeps working with new releases of setuptools.

On the last line: Sure thing, I will update today. I was unsure on that.

As for the minimum version, it would work on at the very least but not
limited to the same versions as before, since it falls back took the
original behavior.

I do agree it would be nice to have automated detection of external API
usage breakage in some manner or another in some version of our future.

This gets rather messy to find the lowest version of setuptools, as pkg_resources uses vendored packaging for the code in question, and to make matters worse distros then do unvendoring, so there are a variety of packaging versions to consider for distro based installs, and a variety of setuptools versions to consider for pypi based installs.
I think we should create a separate issue about it, and work on it after this is merged.  We do know that this works, albeit we have no tests to confirm it.
https://pypi.org/project/entrypoints/ might be helpful.

Just a note that this will bypass the problem with our bears, but the problem will still occur in pygments which we invoke via get_lexer_for_filename , but that might only be in console UI , and maybe doesnt occur in --ci mode.
